subject: RE: [junit] Is there a place for private methods with TDD?
msgSnippet: ... I suspect that the method signatures on A(), B() and C() have been left out for brevity. I don t know of any good answer to as general a situation as this.
messageBody:
> In a class (see below) with two public methods A & B that both call
> private
> method C, what's the best approach for unit testing it? Should test
> scenarios for A or B cover what may happen in C ? If so, is it just

I suspect that the method signatures on A(), B() and C() have been left
out for brevity. I don't know of any good answer to as general a
situation as this. Does C() actually take no parameters, and changes
state of the class, or does C() get passed in the same kind of
parameters from A() and B()? In the former case, maybe it does need to
be a private method. In the latter, might C() be pulled out as a public
method into a helper class?

> If you use TDD would you ever end up with private methods, declaring
them
> as protected instead?

IMHO, it doesn't make sense to make private methods protected simply to
test them. "protected" has a specific purpose in the language, and
unless you are expecting people to write subclasses and override those
methods, they probably shouldn't become protected...

Just my 2 cents...

Regards,
Nilesh
